data.title: Whirlpool (WHR) Is Down 19.0% After Dilutive Recapitalization and Appaloosa Rebuke - Has The Bull Case Changed?
data.description:

The proceeds are earmarked for debt repayment and corporate purposes, directly affecting Whirlpool’s capital structure at a time when its dividend coverage, leverage and profitability are already under scrutiny, and when consensus still expects only modest revenue growth and mid single digit margins.

data.description:

data.title: Nick O. Rowe Joins H2O America Board As Big Investments Loom
data.description:
• H2O America (NasdaqGS:HTO) has appointed Nick O. Rowe to its Board of Directors.
  • Rowe brings nearly four decades of water industry leadership, including senior roles at American Water Works Company and other institutions.
  • The board change comes as H2O America pursues acquisitions and infrastructure investments.

For you as an investor, this move relates to how H2O America plans to handle the practical realities of being a regulated water utility and infrastructure owner. The company operates in a sector where capital spending, customer rates, and regulatory relationships all matter, and where experience with large scale water systems can be particularly valuable. Rowe’s mix of operational and regulatory background aligns with those day to day demands.

His appointment comes at a time when water utilities are often considering larger capital projects, new technology for system reliability, and potential acquisitions. Investors watching NasdaqGS:HTO may view this board addition as an indication that governance and execution are key areas of focus as the company evaluates growth, funding needs, and long term asset planning.

Stay updated on the most important news stories for H2O America by adding it to your watchlist or portfolio. Alternatively, explore our Community to discover new perspectives on H2O America.

Does the team leading H2O America have what it takes? See our full breakdown of the management team's track record and compensation.

For H2O America, Rowe’s arrival comes at a time when board oversight really matters. The company has a pending $540 million Quadvest acquisition, a 2026 to 2030 capital plan of $2.7b, and guidance for 2026 adjusted diluted EPS between $3.08 and $3.18. That combination of higher spending, expected EPS impact from acquisitions in 2026 and 2027, and ongoing regulatory work in several states increases the importance of directors who understand both utility operations and rate-setting.

Advertisement

How This Fits Into The H2O America Narrative

  • Rowe’s background in long-term value creation and large utility operations aligns with H2O America’s focus on capital projects, PFAS treatment and acquisitions such as Quadvest, which were already central to the existing narrative.
  • His emphasis on customer service and affordability could influence how aggressively the company pursues rate increases to support its $2.7b plan, which may differ from assumptions that focus mainly on investment and revenue growth.
  • The narrative highlights technology investments like advanced metering, while this appointment adds a governance angle that was not fully reflected, particularly around board-level oversight of integration risk in Texas.

Knowing what a company is worth starts with understanding its story. Check out one of the top narratives in the Simply Wall St Community for H2O America to help decide what it's worth to you.

The Risks and Rewards Investors Should Consider

  • ⚠️ Large capital plans and acquisitions typically mean higher funding needs, and analysts have noted that interest payments are not well covered by earnings.

The comparison to the Asian insurance industry average P/E of 12x is even more stark. data.title: Is It Time To Reassess Public Storage (PSA) After Recent Share Price Strength
data.description:
• If you are wondering whether Public Storage is fairly priced at around US$307 a share, you are not alone; many investors are trying to work out what they are actually paying for here.
  • The stock has recently posted returns of 0.7% over 7 days, 12.1% over 30 days, 18.8% year to date, 5.4% over 1 year, 13.9% over 3 years, and 61.9% over 5 years, which is prompting fresh questions about both growth potential and risk.
  • Recent coverage has focused on Public Storage as a major US self storage REIT, with investors paying close attention to how the business model fits into the broader real estate sector and demand for storage space. This backdrop helps explain why the market is actively reassessing what a reasonable price might be for the shares today.
  • Right now, our framework gives Public Storage a value score of 4 out of 6, which reflects the number of checks where the stock screens as undervalued. Next, we will walk through the key valuation approaches behind that score, and then finish with a way of looking at valuation that goes a step further.

Public Storage delivered 5.4% returns over the last year. See how this stacks up to the rest of the Specialized REITs industry.

Advertisement

Approach 1: Public Storage Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) Analysis

The DCF model here takes Public Storage’s adjusted funds from operations, projects them into the future, then discounts those cash flows back to today’s dollars to estimate what the business might be worth right now.

On this basis, Public Storage is modeled using a 2 stage Free Cash Flow to Equity approach built on adjusted funds from operations. The latest twelve month free cash flow is about $2.78b. Analyst and extrapolated estimates suggest free cash flow reaching around $3.70b by 2030, with a path that moves through projected figures such as $2.81b in 2026 and $3.46b in 2029, all in US dollars.

After discounting these projected cash flows, the model arrives at an estimated intrinsic value of about $462.30 per share. Compared with the current share price of around $307, this implies a 33.6% discount, which indicates that the shares screen as undervalued under this particular set of assumptions.

Result: UNDERVALUED

Our Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) analysis suggests Public Storage is undervalued by 33.6%. Track this in your watchlist or portfolio, or discover 46 more high quality undervalued stocks.

Head to the Valuation section of our Company Report for more details on how we arrive at this Fair Value for Public Storage.

Approach 2: Public Storage Price vs Earnings

For a profitable company like Public Storage, the P/E ratio is a straightforward way to see what investors are paying for each dollar of earnings. It captures both what the business is earning today and how the market is weighing its prospects and risks.

In general, higher growth expectations and lower perceived risk can support a higher P/E, while slower growth or higher risk usually line up with a lower, more cautious multiple. The question is not whether a P/E is high or low in isolation, but whether it makes sense given the company’s profile.

Public Storage currently trades on a P/E of 33.99x. That sits above the Specialized REITs industry average of 15.86x, and below the peer group average of 41.55x. Simply Wall St’s Fair Ratio for Public Storage is 34.36x, which is its proprietary estimate of a suitable P/E given the company’s earnings growth, industry, profit margins, market cap and key risks. This Fair Ratio can be more informative than a simple peer or industry comparison because it tries to account for the specific mix of growth, risk and profitability that is unique to Public Storage.

With the current P/E of 33.99x very close to the Fair Ratio of 34.36x, the shares screen as ABOUT RIGHT on this metric.

Result: ABOUT RIGHT

Earlier we mentioned that there is an even better way to understand valuation. Narratives let you turn your view of Public Storage into a clear story that links its business outlook to a financial forecast, then to a fair value, all inside Simply Wall St’s Community page where millions of investors share their assumptions.
